Question: Reading from a file without using Scanner: :I'm reading from a pretty simple file that displays items and how much they cost. It looks like this:Shoes 10.00Jersey 20.00Cookies 15.00Light Bulbs 2.00Paper 5.00I want to map every item to how much it costs and my current code works just fine. However, it looks a bit clunky and initializes variables with null that my project's submission server doesn't like and treats as a bug. I'm looking for a way to translate this into something a lot more elegant and thus learn to read files another way apart from relying on the Scanner class. Maybe using BufferedReader or PrintReader or something of the ilk that I have never really grasped. Help appreciated.    private TreeMap<String, Double> prices = new TreeMap<String, Double>();     public void readFromFile(String fileName){                File file = new File(fileName);                Scanner sc = null; //Server treats this as a bug.                 try {                    sc = new Scanner(file);                } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {                    e.printStackTrace();                }                while (sc.hasNextLine()) {                    Scanner sc2 = new Scanner(sc.nextLine());                    while (sc2.hasNext()) {                        String s = sc2.next(); //Gets the item name                        prices.put(s, Double.parseDouble(sc2.next())); //The next word is the price                        }                    sc2.close();                    }}
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.

<<<code>>>: $CODE

Question: Reading from a file without using Scanner: :I'm reading from a pretty simple file that displays items and how much they cost. It looks like this:Shoes 10.00Jersey 20.00Cookies 15.00Light Bulbs 2.00Paper 5.00I want to map every item to how much it costs and my current code works just fine. However, it looks a bit clunky and initializes variables with null that my project's submission server doesn't like and treats as a bug. I'm looking for a way to translate this into something a lot more elegant and thus learn to read files another way apart from relying on the Scanner class. Maybe using BufferedReader or PrintReader or something of the ilk that I have never really grasped. Help appreciated.    private TreeMap<String, Double> prices = new TreeMap<String, Double>();     public void readFromFile(String fileName){                File file = new File(fileName);                Scanner sc = null; //Server treats this as a bug.                 try {                    sc = new Scanner(file);                } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {                    e.printStackTrace();                }                while (sc.hasNextLine()) {                    Scanner sc2 = new Scanner(sc.nextLine());                    while (sc2.hasNext()) {                        String s = sc2.next(); //Gets the item name                        prices.put(s, Double.parseDouble(sc2.next())); //The next word is the price                        }                    sc2.close();                    }}
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: <<<api>>>: StringTokenizer
<<<code>>>: 
```java
private TreeMap<String, Double> prices = new TreeMap<String, Double>();
public void readFromFile(String fileName){
    File file = new File(fileName);
    try {
        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(file));
        String line;
        while ((line = br.readLine()) != null) {
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line);
            String item = st.nextToken(); //Gets the item name
            Double price = Double.parseDouble(st.nextToken()); //The next word is the price
            prices.put(item, price);
        }
        br.close();
    } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    } catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we use a BufferedReader to read the file line by line. For each line, we use a StringTokenizer to split the line into tokens. The first token is the item name, and the second token is the price. We then use the put method of the TreeMap to add the item and its price to the map.

Note: This code assumes that the file is properly formatted with one item per line, with the item name followed by its price. If the file is not properly formatted, this code may not work as expected.
